rsa_ml_attacks.name: RSA ML Attacks
rsa_ml_attacks.short_description: Investigating the attacks on the RSA encryption algorithm using maching learning
rsa_ml_attacks.long_description_old: RSA_ML_Attacks is a research-oriented project that explores how machine learning techniques can be used to analyze and potentially attack the RSA encryption algorithm. It focuses on generating synthetic RSA datasets and applying ML models to uncover patterns that may compromise cryptographic security. The project simulates attack scenarios to assess the practical viability of ML-based approaches in cryptanalysis. It aims to bridge the gap between traditional cryptographic methods and modern AI capabilities. The codebase is modular, supporting easy experimentation with different models and parameters. Key components include data generation, feature extraction, model training, and results evaluation. It serves as an educational and research tool for students and professionals interested in cybersecurity, cryptography, and machine learning. The project is implemented in Python and includes Docker support for consistent environments.

blocks.value: is a research project I created to explore how machine learning can be used to analyze and challenge the security of RSA encryption, one of the most widely used cryptographic algorithms in the world.

The goal of this project is to investigate whether patterns in RSA-related data can be learned by machine learning models and potentially used to perform or assist in cryptographic attacks. It sits at the intersection of artificial intelligence and cybersecurity.

This work is meant to contribute to the academic and technical understanding of how modern AI techniques might influence cryptographic security, either by revealing new vulnerabilities or inspiring more robust encryption strategies.
Researchers interested in the intersection of cryptography and machine learning.
Students studying cybersecurity, cryptanalysis, or data science.
Developers and academics curious about how AI could be applied in cryptographic contexts.

kibit.name: Kibit
kibit.short_description: A version controlled file saving system
kibit.long_description_old: Kibit is a desktop application developed using the Kivy framework, designed to facilitate the backup of local directories to private Git repositories. The tool provides a user-friendly interface where users can configure their Git repository settings, including repository URL and authentication credentials. Once set up, users can select local directories to back up, and the application will synchronize these directories with the specified Git repository. This ensures that users have a secure and version-controlled backup of their important files. The application is particularly useful for developers and individuals who prefer using Git for backup purposes but seek a straightforward graphical interface to manage the process. The project is open-source and available for contributions.

blocks.value: is a Git backup tool I developed using the Kivy framework. It provides a graphical user interface (GUI) to facilitate easy backup of local Git repositories to a remote repository.

The primary objective of Kibit is to simplify the process of backing up local files and folders by offering an intuitive interface that allows users to configure and manage their backup settings effortlessly.
Kibit is designed for anyone who prefer a Git-powered version control system on their personal files, eliminating the need to look for a backup device.
Offers a simple and intuitive GUI built with the Kivy framework, making it accessible to users of all technical levels.
Allows users to set up and configure their private Git repositories for backup purposes.
Provides options to set relative paths, offering flexibility in managing backup locations.

The tool works by comparing the links found on a web page against a predefined set of trusted sources. If any unexpected or suspicious links are detected, they are flagged for further review. dr-bst.name: DRLearning Basket Shot Trajectory (DR-BST)
dr-bst.short_description: DRLearning Basket Shot Trajectory (DR-BST) is a deep reinforcement learning-based simulation that trains an agent to optimize basketball shot trajectories through dynamic angle and force adjustments.
dr-bst.long_description_old: DRLearning-Basket-Shot-Trajectory is a Python-based simulation that employs deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to model and optimize basketball shot trajectories. The project utilizes the Kivy framework to provide an interactive graphical interface, allowing users to visualize and adjust various parameters influencing the shot. Key components of the simulation include classes for the ball, rim, and power bar, each contributing to the realistic modeling of the shot dynamics. The agent learns to adjust the shot's angle and force to maximize the likelihood of scoring, simulating the decision-making process of a basketball player. The environment is designed to be extensible, enabling the incorporation of additional features such as player movement or defensive interference. The project's structure is modular, with separate files handling different aspects of the simulation, including physics calculations and user interface elements. A Jupyter Notebook is included for testing and experimentation with different configurations. The repository provides a foundational platform for exploring the application of DRL in sports simulations. This project is particularly useful for those interested in the intersection of artificial intelligence and sports analytics. It serves as an educational tool for understanding the principles of reinforcement learning in a practical context.

This project is intended for sports enthusiasts, students, and anyone interested in the physics of basketball shooting.
